title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: A situation where a unanimous decision is always the best outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: A situation where the closer you get to total agreement, the less reliable the result becomes.

options.label: C
options.text: A situation where a majority vote is always the best way to make a decision.

options.label: D
options.text: A situation where a single person's opinion is more important than the majority.

multiple-choice.question: Why might a unanimous identification of a suspect by witnesses be unreliable?

options.label: B
options.text: Because witnesses are never confident in their choices.

options.label: C
options.text: Because memory based on short glimpses can be unreliable, and witnesses often overestimate their own accuracy.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup, according to a 1994 study?
What is an example of a systemic error mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: A coin toss resulting in 100% heads.

options.label: C
options.text: The contamination of DNA samples by a woman working in a swab factory.

options.label: D
options.text: A presidential referendum with a 100% turnout and 100% of voters voting in favor of the incumbent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the elusive killer whose DNA was found at multiple crime scenes around Europe?
Why might a result of 100% heads in 100 coin tosses be suspicious?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it suggests that something is wrong with the coin.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a situation where unanimous agreement might be expected?

options.label: A
options.text: Identifying a suspect in a lineup.

options.label: C
options.text: Predicting the outcome of a coin toss.

options.label: D
options.text: Determining the winner of a presidential election.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: That unanimous agreement is always the best outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: That unanimous agreement is always suspicious.

options.label: C
options.text: That in situations where perfect agreement is highly unlikely, achieving it may indicate a hidden factor affecting the system.

options.label: D
options.text: That majority vote is always the best way to make a decision.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the presidential referendum held by Saddam Hussein in 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: A turnout of 50% of voters with 50% voting in favor of another seven-year term.

options.label: B
options.text: A turnout of 100% of voters with 50% voting in favor of another seven-year term.

options.label: C
options.text: A turnout of 50% of voters with 100% voting in favor of another seven-year term.

options.label: D
options.text: A turnout of 100% of voters with 100% voting in favor of another seven-year term.

multiple-choice.question: Why might error and disagreement be naturally expected in many situations?

options.label: B
options.text: Because people are never confident in their choices.

options.label: C
options.text: Because many situations involve uncertainty and variability.

title: Why the insect brain is so incredible - Anna Stöckl

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They had a similar nervous system to humans

options.label: D
options.text: They had a highly developed sense of smell

multiple-choice.question: What is a key difference between the human nervous system and the insect nervous system?

options.text: The human nervous system is decentralized, while the insect nervous system is centralized

options.label: B
options.text: The human nervous system is centralized, while the insect nervous system is decentralized

options.label: C
options.text: The human nervous system is more complex, while the insect nervous system is simpler

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: That insects are not capable of complex behaviors

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: Why is this painting so captivating? - James Earle and Christina Bozsik

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of the royal family

options.label: C
options.text: King Philip IV and Queen Mariana

options.text: The rise of the Spanish Empire

title: A shark-deterrent wetsuit (and it's not what you think)

multiple-choice.question: What was the motivation behind the development of Shark Attack Mitigation Systems (SAMS) technology?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new fashion trend in wetsuits

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the risk of shark attacks on humans

options.label: C
options.text: To study the behavior of sharks in their natural habitat

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new material for wetsuits

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary sensor used by sharks to identify their target?
What was the advice given by Harry Butler to mitigate shark attacks?

options.label: A
options.text: Wear a black wetsuit to blend in with the water

options.label: B
options.text: Wear a wetsuit with yellow stripes like a bumblebee

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid surfing in areas with known shark activity

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the university that collaborated with SAMS to develop the technology?
According to Professor Nathan Hart's research, how do predatory sharks see the world?

options.label: B
options.text: In black and white or grayscale

options.label: C
options.text: With a combination of color and grayscale

options.label: D
options.text: With a heightened sense of smell

multiple-choice.question: What are the two key characteristics that the SAMS technology aims to achieve?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the wearer visible and attractive to sharks

options.label: B
options.text: To make the wearer invisible and unattractive to sharks

options.label: C
options.text: To make the wearer appear as a shark's natural prey

options.label: D
options.text: To make the wearer appear as a shark's predator

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the wetsuit designed to provide a highly disruptive profile and prevent sharks from considering the wearer as ordinary food?

options.label: A
options.text: By putting humans in the water with sharks

options.label: B
options.text: By using humanoid shapes and baiting them up in the water

options.label: C
options.text: By using a perforated drum with bait and wrapping it in a neoprene skin

multiple-choice.question: What were the results of the testing, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The sharks were attracted to the SAMS technology

options.label: B
options.text: The sharks were indifferent to the SAMS technology

options.label: C
options.text: The sharks were less likely to engage with the SAMS technology

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Using science to study the behavior of animals

options.label: D

title: The origins of ballet - Jennifer Tortorello and Adrienne Westwood

multiple-choice.question: What was the original purpose of ballet in Renaissance Italy?

options.label: A
options.text: As a form of entertainment for the general public

options.label: B
options.text: As a combination of social dance and choreographed display at aristocratic gatherings

options.label: C
options.text: As a way to tell stories through movement

options.label: D
options.text: As a form of exercise for the nobility

multiple-choice.question: Who brought ballet to France in the 16th century?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of his reign as king

options.label: B
options.text: It cemented the central role ballet would play during his reign

options.label: C
options.text: It was his first performance as a professional dancer

options.label: D
options.text: It was his last performance as a dancer

multiple-choice.question: What was the main contribution of Louis XIV to ballet?

options.label: A
options.text: He performed in 80 roles in 40 major ballets

options.label: B
options.text: He founded the Royal Academy of Dance in 1661

options.label: C
options.text: He codified the five main positions of the body

options.label: D
options.text: He made ballet a required skill for all gentlemen

multiple-choice.question: Who codified the five main positions of the body still used in ballet today?

options.label: A
options.text: Ballet became a required skill for all gentlemen

options.label: B
options.text: Control of ballet shifted from local guilds to the royal court

options.label: C
options.text: The Paris Opera Ballet was founded

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Paris Opera Ballet?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first ballet company in the world

options.label: B
options.text: It was the oldest ballet company in the world

options.label: C
options.text: It was the largest ballet company in the world

options.label: D
options.text: It was the most famous ballet company in the world

multiple-choice.question: How did the advent of the romantic movement affect ballet?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decline in the popularity of ballet

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in the founding of the Royal Academy of Dance

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the development of new ballet techniques

options.label: D
options.text: It introduced fantasy and folklore themes as common motifs

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the influence of ballet in France over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased and became a central part of French culture

options.label: B
options.text: It remained the same and continued to be a popular form of entertainment

options.label: C
options.text: It declined, but other countries such as Russia played a major role in its further development

multiple-choice.question: How has ballet evolved over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It has remained a static and unchanging art form

options.label: B
options.text: It has become more rigid and formalized

options.label: C
options.text: It has become more expressive and dynamic

options.label: D
options.text: It has moved from the royal court to the theater and survived democratic revolutions and reforms

title: Can you solve the frog riddle? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: You are stranded in a rainforest and need an antidote produced by a specific species of frog. What is the key difference between the male and female frogs of this species?
You see a frog on a tree stump and hear a male frog croak coming from a clearing in the opposite direction. What do you see in the clearing?
What is the probability of any one frog being either sex, assuming a roughly equal number of males and females?
Why is the logic of a 50% chance of any one frog being female incorrect for the clearing?

options.label: A
options.text: The frogs are not independent of each other

options.label: B
options.text: The probability changes due to the additional information from the croak

options.label: C
options.text: The number of frogs in the clearing is unknown

options.label: D
options.text: The sex of the frogs is already known

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct probability of getting at least one female frog in the clearing?
What is the concept that explains why the probability changes in this scenario?
How does the croak of the male frog affect the sample space of possible combinations?

options.label: B
options.text: It eliminates the possibility of a pair of females

options.label: C
options.text: It changes the probability of each combination

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the sample space

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of eliminating possibilities from the sample space?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of getting a particular combination decreases

options.label: B
options.text: The probability of getting a particular combination increases

options.label: C
options.text: The sample space remains the same

multiple-choice.question: Where else is conditional probability used besides abstract mathematical games?

options.label: B
options.text: In computers and other devices to detect errors

options.label: C
options.text: In life decisions to narrow down choices

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of the scenario with the poisonous mushroom and the frogs?

options.label: A
options.text: To illustrate the concept of independent probability

options.label: B
options.text: To show the importance of avoiding poisonous mushrooms

options.label: C
options.text: To demonstrate how information affects probability

options.label: D
options.text: To explain the concept of sample space
